At that time, Udayin himself entered the forest and saw the Bodhisattva lying on the ground, covered in dust from head to toe, without any radiance, the same color as the earth, his body emaciated, with no flesh or skin left, only bones and skin wrapped around his body.

'Who is this?
His inner mind was like this, sorrowful and distressed, as if burned by fire, he cried and spoke.
At that time, the upÄsikÄ replied to the Bodhisattva, saying:

King Åšuddhodana, the prince's father, sent me here to accompany and welcome the prince.'
The Bodhisattva replied:

At that time, UdÄyin again consulted and requested the Bodhisattva, saying:

The Bodhisattva then replied to UdÄyin, saying:

'I only wish that my body here would be shattered, like sesame seeds, white powder, and fine dust, if I cannot attain self-benefit and benefiting others. My mind of diligence will never let go and become lazy.

At that time, Udayin said to the Bodhisattva:
'Great Sage Prince!

If the prince today has such a sincere vow and perhaps has not yet attained self-benefit and benefiting others, and his life ends, how can I dare to abandon the prince, go against my original vow, and return to Kapilavastu with an empty face?'
At that time, the Bodhisattva again said to Udayin:
'You, Udayin!
If I do not attain my own benefit while practicing austerities here, and my life ends in the middle of this, O Udayin!
Take my corpse, carry it out of the original gate, and carry it into the city of Kapilavastu.
You should also speak these words for me to all the people inside and outside the city of Kapilavastu, saying:
This is the one who is diligent, not a person of idle talk, who made a vow with a right mind and right heart, a body of bones.
You, Udayin!
You should also answer my father the king's message for me, and tell my father these words:
Great King!

You should know that the prince has already given rise to diligent effort, and has now given up his life, not because of laziness. One who speaks the truth, now that he has given up his life, is not a liar.
You, Udayin!
Although I am like this now, while I was in this forest, I had a dream at night like this: countless gods came to me in secret, bowed their heads at my feet, and said to me:
Prince Siddhartha, you should now give rise to great joy. From now on, within seven days, you will surely accomplish the greatest benefit.
You, Udayin!
I have had this dream, it will not be in vain.
You, Udayin!
Now you may return home. I do not need you as a friend.
At that time, Udayin, having heard the Bodhisattva's vow like this, had no hope in the Bodhisattva's mind, and immediately left the forest where the Bodhisattva was sitting.
Having left, he returned to the city of Kapilavastu. Seeing King Shuddhodana, he immediately said to King Shuddhodana:
'Great King!

King Åšuddhodana said:

Having heard these words, he was overjoyed.

At that time, MÄra, the demon king of the desire realm, wanting to create disturbances for the Bodhisattva, during the six years of his ascetic practice, always closely attended the Bodhisattva on the left and right, looking for an opportunity, but could not find the slightest fault.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
The place of tranquility is already excellent, the trees and forests are very beautiful,
To the east of UrubilvÄ village, next to the bank of the NairaÃ±janÄ River,
Having selected the site there, he vowed to sit firmly in full lotus position,

The demon king PÄpÄ«yÄn came to him, and with false kind words said:
May you, O virtuous one, have a long life. With a long life, one can practice the Dharma.

Your body now is very weak. You will definitely die before long.
In truth, you are now a thousand times dead. With a little merit, perhaps one part may survive.
Just give a lot of offerings and serve the gods, and make sacrifices to the fire gods.
In this way, you may obtain great merit. What is the use of practicing meditation?
Seeking the supreme path of renunciation is very difficult, and taming one's own mind is also not easy.ğŸ”½The demon king thus praised the Bodhisattva with various words,
And the Bodhisattva then replied with subtle and skillful words and sounds:
PÄpÄ«yÄn, you are not good, you are negligent, seeking self-benefit you act in the world,

I view the suffering of death as if it were birth, I truly do not fear extinction for a single moment,
If all sentient beings were to perish, my mind would never turn back for a moment,
Now I build a great bridge across the sea of desire, diligently and bravely practicing pure conduct.
Therefore, when a wind disaster arises in the world, it can still dry up all flowing waters,
How much more so the moisture within this body, can its liquid not be dried up?
The oil and marrow will first be exhausted, then the skin and flesh will wither,
When the flesh is gone and the skin stands out, with little strength, the mind and intention can then attain tranquility,
Only by entering the door of samÄdhi can one increase all kinds of vigor.
When I now wish to practice this practice, I hope to reach that supreme enlightenment,
Therefore I do not begrudge this life and body, you must know my pure mind within.
My mind now has this utmost sincerity, the adornment of wisdom is very firm,
In the world, I have not seen anyone who can cut off this vigor of mine.
I would rather die and have my life taken away, I will not live at home for a long time,
A hero would rather die in battle, than live under the control of others.
A strong man can subdue others, having subdued them, what more is there to fear?
Only the strong can break through all enemies, I will not be long before I subdue you, MÄra.
Your army's first is desire and greed, the second is called discontent,

At that time, the Bodhisattva further thought like this:ğŸ”½'If there are Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as who, in the past, for the sake of seeking their own benefit, experienced great suffering, either with an unhappy mind or with both body and mind unhappy, the suffering they experienced is no more than this.

The Bodhisattva further thought like this:

'You two sisters!

At that time, there was a shepherd's son who saw the Bodhisattva, due to his ascetic practices, his body was greatly emaciated. The Bodhisattva replied:

At that time, the shepherd then massaged the Bodhisattva's body, took some sheep's milk, offered it to the Bodhisattva to eat.

At that time, when the Bodhisattva was eating coarse food, those five sages said to each other:
Siddhattha Prince has now lost his meditation and returned to his original nature, let alone not keeping the precepts.
He is now a lazy person, unable to attain tranquility, and his mind is in turmoil.
Having made such a judgment, they became tired of the Bodhisattva, slandered him, abandoned him, and went their separate ways.
Gradually, they reached the country of Varanasi, entered the Deer Park, and practiced meditation.
There is a verse:
The five ascetics who practiced austerities saw the Bodhisattva eating coarse food,
And said, 'He has no practice of meditation, indulges in self-nourishment, and has a large body of the five elements.'
At that time, when the Bodhisattva wished to seek coarse food, he only wanted to make his body gain a little strength.

At that time, the daughter of the village chief named SubhadrÄ, from the very beginning when she saw the Bodhisattva, rose up on that day to make offerings of cooked food and utensils for the Bodhisattva, and if she made offerings to others,

When the milk porridge was being cooked, there was a good astrologer who understood the calculations of the ocean and divination. He came to that place and saw the various appearances of the milk porridge. After observing well, he said like this:

Who can obtain this milk porridge and eat it?
After that person eats it, he will soon realize the wonderful medicine of nectar.

At that time, the Bodhisattva reached the twenty-third day of the second month. In the morning, he put on his robes properly and wanted to go to the village of UrubilvÄ to beg for food. He gradually reached the village of NandÄ±ka.
